Alexandre Teplitxky is a distinguished marketing leader with over a decade of experience in the construction technology sector. He has held pivotal roles at renowned companies such as Procore and Autodesk, where he honed his skills in driving strategic marketing initiatives. Currently, Alexandre spearheads marketing at SmartPM Technologies, a trailblazer in AI-driven project management solutions. His passion for optimizing workflows extends beyond his professional endeavors, as he actively invests in prefabrication startups, supporting innovative entrepreneurs in the industry. Outside of work, Alexandre is an avid traveler, having explored over 60 countries, and a paragliding enthusiast, based in the scenic city of Santa Barbara, California.

In this episode, we delve into the complexities of construction payroll management, characterized by scattered teams, frequent site changes, and language barriers. Albert Bou Fadel, Founder & CEO of SmartBarrel, discusses how their cutting-edge technology addresses these challenges by capturing time data directly from the jobsite, automating approval processes, and integrating with payroll systems. This approach not only reduces financial risks but also enhances visibility into labor costs in real time.

Albert Bou Fadel is a visionary entrepreneur in the construction industry, known for his innovative approach to labor management. Before founding SmartBarrel, he successfully ran a glazing company, gaining firsthand experience with the challenges of construction timekeeping. As the CEO of SmartBarrel, Albert leads the development of a platform that combines field-ready hardware with intuitive software, revolutionizing how construction sites manage labor and time. His dedication to creating practical solutions has positioned SmartBarrel as a leader in the industry.

In this insightful episode, we delve into the cutting-edge tools and resources that are transforming construction timekeeping. SmartBarrel stands out as a pivotal solution, seamlessly integrating rugged hardware with intuitive software to streamline jobsite operations. Its compatibility with leading payroll systems like Procore, Vista, and CMiC ensures that data flows effortlessly, minimizing errors and maximizing efficiency. Discover how these tools are not just simplifying processes but also empowering construction teams to focus on what truly matters—building with precision and confidence.

James Poen, President and part-owner of Richardson Saw & Lawn Mower, has been instrumental in transforming the company from a local shop into a leading outdoor power equipment dealership. Jack Carrere is the dynamic founder and CEO of Prokeep, a pioneering software company that is reshaping communication in the distribution industry. Under his leadership, Prokeep has grown from a local startup to a national powerhouse, serving over 1,000 distributors and 40,000 users. Jack's innovative approach and commitment to customer success have been instrumental in raising over $37 million in venture funding, driving the company's continued expansion and impact.

Join Henry Harrison as he engages in a thought-provoking conversation with Chaitanya NK, the visionary CEO of Track 3D. This episode delves into the transformative power of AI and 3D technology in the construction industry. Discover how Track 3D is pioneering new methods to enhance efficiency, reduce costs, and improve safety on construction sites. Chaitanya shares his journey from a tech enthusiast to a leader in construction innovation, offering listeners a glimpse into the future of building and infrastructure management.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="default" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_column type="4_4" _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="default" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_toggle title="Podcast Transcript" _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="default" global_colors_info="{}"]NKpodcast === Henry Harrison: [00:00:00] Well, it's gonna be a terrific podcast today, the Henry Harrison podcast, entrepreneurs Business and Finance. We're fortunate to have NK co-founder and CEO of Track 3D and this is one of a number of companies that he has founded over the years, and he's been working on this one for almost four years. So we've got a lot of good, good things to talk about. Hello, NK. Chaitanya NK: Hey, Henry. Thanks for having me. Excited to have this conversation. Henry Harrison: Terrific. Well, let's talk a little bit about what Track 3D does. I know it has to do with technology and, and helping keep up construction. I have a somewhat of a background in construction. I had a custom home building company for 10 years. Probably not your target market. Probably bigger projects with but I still know the chaos and the need for, for control and data and management. It is an ever ever difficult, forever difficult process in construction. So I, I hope you're able to improve that and I hope you are improving [00:01:00] that. Chaitanya NK: Absolutely, Henry. So you will be able to even understand this context a lot better, I guess because, you know, you know, most construction projects go either over budget, over schedule. In most cases, both of them actually. So we help to keep construction projects on track. That is what Track three does. And how we do that is by automating construction monitoring, like you can capture the site. With a moving camera, it could be a robot, a drone, or a person walking around with a camera. And our AI engine automatically tells you how much of work has been done, what has been done, when it has been done, and also has it been done to the right specifications or not without any manual input. So all just hold your mobile. Walk around a single family home, for example, and the system will automatically tell you everything that's been installed. So this helps you to proactively track your [00:02:00] project. You're always on top of it. You know when things are going wrong so that you can actually mitigate the risk and help keep the project on track. That is the number one thing we do. Henry Harrison: So I'm just looking here. You didn't just all of a sudden. Learned how to start this company. You a software engineer, so you learned how to, to program and meet a software. You started a company in 2015. You start another one. I guess you work full time, then you started another one, then another one. Now this one. So you're what you call a serial entrepreneur. And this one in particular, you've raised $10 million of a seed round, so you must be investing a lot in the technology right now. Chaitanya NK: Okay, Henry. So it's been a long journey, in fact, we are three co-founders and two of us have been on this journey for more than 15 years now, and all the three of us have been working together for eight years. So we have been gone a long, long time. We are [00:03:00] friends since high school, all the three of us actually, so we know each other more than what we know of our wives. So that's what we say. But I'll tell you about me to start with, right? Did my computer science graduation and back in 2007 was when I started my first company. So it was very clear. I did an internship in a company, which I would not name before that, and that internship gave me enough insights to say that, you know, I'm not meant for the corporate world. I like building new things, you know, building impactful things, and working on cutting edge technology has always been my passion. Inside that also, I was very fortunate to work on some really, really good technology early on. So 3D vision, ai, robotics, and iot, right? The combination of all these 10 technologies was what was super fascinating for me because. [00:04:00] I simply couldn't understand a picture or a blueprint if you apply it for the construction scenario, you take a blueprint and try to understand and visualize it in 3D, I was never able to actually visualize it that well, so I felt that, you know, pictures are worth a thousand words they say, but if you take pictures and convert it into a 3D, that is actually worth a million words. So that way, right. I've worked very early on in different domains. Started out in the medical domain, then home automation, industrial automation, furniture, augmented reality to our last startup, which was in the smart cities domain, like we were creating digital replicas of entire cities using drones, robots, cards, whatnot. And that led us into the world of construction actually, because cities do a lot of construction. We were helping sitting administrators track what is happening on their job sites, [00:05:00] and that's when we also understood that construction is a large global problem that if technology applied right can unlock so many amazing benefits that I was talking about. So we started Track 3D four years back, said, you know, let's apply all our expertise and technology that we have gained over the years to solve what is like a trillion dollar industry's problem on a global scale. Right? And the problem is, same, you do a construction site in US or in India. Today data from the ground is being collected in manually. And manually collected data is either inconsistent, incomplete, inaccurate, or inaccessible actually. So stakeholders of the project never get the right data at the right time to make the right decisions. We thought by smartly applying technology, we can solve that. So that was a genesis of Track 3D and my genesis as an entrepreneur all throughout, and you are right to one more question that you asked. All my [00:06:00] previous ventures or all our previous ventures, we have never rush any venture funding before and this is the first time we are doing it because, you know we were very thoughtful of the kind of impact that we want to create. We knew that, you know, having the right partners on board to support our mission along with this right ammunition is rated to actually create that impact on the global scale. So yes, we are again, fortunate to be backed by some of the leading you know, construction tech VCs and others. And we, it's been four years. We have raised total of about $14.3 million. We just announced our CDCA couple about one month back. Henry Harrison: So where are you in the process right now? Do you have clients? Are you going to market? Yes. Chaitanya NK: Yes, yes. Have Henry. You know, we started, as I told you, four years back, the first one and a half year was about co-development and understanding the customer requirements and all that. But we have been commercially available in the [00:07:00] market over the last two years now, and again, have been super fortunate to be working with some of the largest construction companies in the us. Henry Harrison: Oh, terrific. Track 3D has been a game-changer in the construction industry, providing innovative solutions that have saved time and money on numerous projects. For instance, at a major airport construction site, Track 3D identified an HVAC duct installed incorrectly, preventing costly rework. In another project, the technology detected missing sprinkler heads before ceiling panels were closed, saving extensive labor and time. These examples highlight the power of automated, visual verification, ensuring projects remain on schedule and within budget.

Track 3D is at the forefront of a technological revolution in the construction industry, merging AI, robotics, and computer vision to create a seamless reality intelligence system. This platform not only documents but also analyzes every aspect of a job site, aiming to become the operating system for all physical assets throughout their lifecycle. With advancements in autonomous drones and robotic site walkers, Track 3D is poised to transform construction into a data-driven industry, making information accessible, actionable, and automated.

Looking ahead, Track 3D envisions a world where construction projects are managed with precision and efficiency, minimizing errors and maximizing productivity. By integrating cutting-edge technology with user-friendly interfaces, the company is committed to simplifying complex processes, ensuring that construction teams can focus on building rather than troubleshooting. As Track 3D continues to expand its reach, it is set to redefine the standards of construction management globally.

podcasts.guestBio: Join Henry Harrison as he engages in a thought-provoking conversation with Chaitanya NK, the visionary CEO of Track 3D. This episode delves into the transformative power of AI and 3D technology in the construction industry. Discover how Track 3D is pioneering new methods to enhance efficiency, reduce costs, and improve safety on construction sites. Chaitanya shares his journey from a tech enthusiast to a leader in construction innovation, offering listeners a glimpse into the future of building and infrastructure management.

Glenn Poulos

Henry Harrison: [00:00:00] So we are very fortunate today to have Glenn Poulos on the show and I had to ask him how to pronounce that name, so I think I got it right. But Entrepreneurs Business and Finance, the Henry Harrison Show, and Glenn is a business owner, and this is his third business liaison. He also informally coaches entrepreneurs.

He's a public speaker. He's written a book. He's an AI enthusiast. But I would have to say all that ties in from our brief conversation so far, which we'll learn more about to his passion for owning and running businesses. So welcome to the show, Glenn. Hello. 

Glenn Poulos: Hi, Henry. Hi, Henry. Thanks for having me.

It's great to be here. 

Henry Harrison: So tell us a little bit. It's, it's a lot but what you're doing right now. Sure. And we'll start with that and then we'll look at how you got here and some other things. 

Glenn Poulos: Yeah. So in 2022, I sold a company which I had been running for 15 years. And I stayed on with the private equity [00:01:00] people for a period of time.

But during I saw the, you know, the, the way that thing would play out and you know, the, the owners sort of scale out of the businesses. So I thought. I'm not really ready to go off in the sunset quite yet. And you know large family just gotta make sure enough is enough, you know? And so I thought, why not do it again?

See if I can do it again. So as I was transitioning out of my old business with the private equity. The new owners. I bought a business in a new industry but in a similar kind of business that would allow me to sort of take what I'd learned in my last two companies and apply them again, but also stay on side for my, my litany of no competes that I had when I sold the business to the private equity. So I'm, I'm running that business now. I changed so in order to stay safe, I, I I changed technologies from telecom to power. I changed customers from telcos to utilities, and I changed countries from the Canada to the US.

So I pretty much changed everything just to be on the safe side. But I'm running, running the same kind of business [00:02:00] distributor of high tech electronic equipment used for testing and measurement of you know, signals and the like, but instead of being in the telecom space, now I'm in the in the power utility space.

Henry Harrison: Terrific. Okay. And how did you find that business? What, what was the search like to hey, I want to go find a business. Obviously has some criteria, but where do you look? 

Glenn Poulos: Yeah, I mean the place you can find like Biz Buy Sell is really one of the sort of go-to places for that kind of and you can sort by distribution companies and medical companies and you know, printing companies.

You can sort by any host of, of types of businesses. And of course, my mine specialty is wholesale distribution. And that's a good way. I came, you know, it was kind of serendipity the way I came across this one. I had bumped into an old colleague who suggested another colleague was retiring.

And the timing was really good and I got together and that's how we sort of fell together. And but. I did find a lot of very suitable and in [00:03:00] using the biz buy sell method. But that's not how I exactly bought this company. So I was referred to it by someone else. 

Henry Harrison: And you've got so many companies.

I wanna make sure I get it right. What, what is this company? 

Glenn Poulos: This is Prog USA, so GAP Wireless was the company I sold to private equity, which became NWS, and then I retired. After a certain period of time, and then I bought this business in Florida called Prog USA. And when, when did you buy that?

So I bought that in January of 2024, and I was still working in the old company and the old owner was still running it. And then in January of 2025 when I finished at my old business which had a new name by this time, you know I, I'd already owned it for a year, but I was I then joined them full-time last January.

So I'm coming up on a one year in the new company. 

Henry Harrison: Sure. Okay. So, that's your third company. So take us through a journey of how you became a guy that can write a book, be asked to coach informally and and buy a third [00:04:00] company. Where did that all start? Because that's a lot of people's dream is to do what you've done.

Yeah. And people are in the midst of doing it, buying, selling, starting thinking. 

Glenn Poulos: Yeah, so I st I started by getting kicked out of the Canadian government as a civil servant. And as I like to tell the story, my boss thought, thought I was in the wrong field. He, he said, you should go into sales. And I don't know what he saw.

He saw something, I guess, and I took him at his word. I was in my early twenties and he said, I don't think you're cut out for a lifetime, working as a civil servant. And I probably somewhat agree with him. And so I got a job in sales. And it was selling high tech electronic equipment. And and I noticed how, you know, how much control I call sort of sales, kind of a cheat code for for increasing your income because, you know, you can, you don't need to have 14 years of medical diplomas, you know, to make the money that a surgeon makes.

You can make that in sales and you can make it much faster than a surgeon can make, you know, the money they're making [00:05:00] based on your capability to learn products, learn customers, and, and grow and nurture your, you know, your business. Right? And so there's not many other businesses that allow you to do that.

Right. You know, you become an accountant, something like that. I mean, you know, you're gonna go through a certain number of steps, you're gonna make a certain amount of money, and it's pretty much laid out the way it's all gonna work. Right. But in sales, you can sort of leap scotch up by being good at the job, right?

The more you sell, the more you make and and you can create points of leverage in, in the products. But all I learned that the owners of the company were making even more money. 'cause they had a bunch of salesmen like me running around doing the selling plus themselves. And so when, when I sold, they got paid.

When they sold, they got paid. So after about five and a half years, I, I approached them about starting a business. They turned me down and and so I, I suggested we break off a piece of their technology they were selling into, and let me focus on it, right? They, they really didn't have any interest in doing that.

And they, they wanted me to stick [00:06:00] to my knitting. And so I I promptly quit that job and without much warning. And and I started my first business in 1991. I was 29 and a half. And I'd been selling for about five and a half years at the time. And and I was, you know, I suggested we should focus on this new fangled technology that I thought was going to be take off.

And of course it was the cell phone. Of course that never went anywhere, right? I mean, that industry never, never took off at all. Right? Who, who needs a cell phone? Right? And and so, you know, I, I focused a business on helping in the Canadian market. This was building, maintaining a cellular network, not selling cell phones, but selling the network side of the equipment, radios and antennas and tower products and cable and.

Everything that that goes into building and owning and operating a cellular network. Right? And that's, that, that was the first business I sold it and I was able to, I've had the freedom to start a second one and I sort of focused even a little bit [00:07:00] more, which became the GAP Wireless in 2007. And and I had yeah, it's, and I ran that for 15 years and then I sold it to private equity, which was in 2022.

Worked for them until 2024, the end of 24. And now I'm, now I'm in Prague, USA, in Florida on my third business, selling the same kind of equipment, but more in the power generation, power monitoring field in the utility space. Looking, you know, looking to capitalize on the expanding and exploding market for, for power to drive data centers and things like that, which I feel is going to grow much, much more than the telecom over the next five to 10 years.

Henry Harrison: You know people sometimes give sales a bad wrap. My first job was in construction. Became a kind of assistant construction supervisor, is what they called back in the day for a home builder. And then I went into sales because somewhere along the line, I, I majored in economics at Emory University, but [00:08:00] somewhere along the line, I, I learned that people have to have things explained properly to them.

And people have to, they have to find a way to know what you have if it is for sale and then they want to buy it, I think with people too often, although respect car dealers the old way where no one wants to go buy a car 'cause you gotta go in there and haggle with some sales person who's just trying to get more money outta you.

So you must be continuing all these years to add value to people when they're selling them, because there's something where people don't want to be sold, but they do wanna buy what they wanna buy. And can you talk a little bit about that, because I know you're, you're proud of what you do, you like to share it to other people, and you're not trying to sell somebody something they don't need or something want just the opposite.

You're trying to find what is right for That's right. 

Glenn Poulos: Yeah, that's right. Well, my first response whenever people talk about sales is I'm like, well, nobody, nobody does anything until something gets sold, right? That's right. So you can have the best mouse trap in the world, you know, manufacturing, you know, a million mouse traps an hour in your factory.

But unless someone's out [00:09:00] there selling those mouse traps, nobody and someone's buying them the factory's gonna be pretty quiet, right? So nothing happens until something gets sold, right? So sales is kind of the beginning of the you know, the food chain for me and you know I sort of defend it vigorously.

Right. But, you know, when, you know, as the years rolled on, I, I realized that I needed to develop a system on how to get, act and stay in front of my customers and how to be a pleasure to do business with always. And that's sort of all the tips and tricks that went into the book that we can chat about later.

And, but I realized that, you know, people wanna deal with people that are not a pain in the butt. Right? Like, and you know, like you don't wanna be that guy, right? And and so I've spent a lifetime figuring out all the ways and means how to not be that guy you just talked about in the car dealership, right?

And how do I figure out ways of getting in front of my customers, staying in front of them, and acting in front of them so that they consider me a pleasure to do business with [00:10:00] always, even when they have to tell me, no, I can't buy from you because my customers are huge customers that I've sold to for many years, not just one and done.

It's not like, you know, you sell 'em a car and never care if they ever come back again. Right. I mean, I would the customers I had in my old last two companies, I had them for a collective of 15 years each, right? And and so I didn't get all the business. And so when I didn't, I still wanted them to invite me back on the next deal because you don't wanna behave poorly.

You know when you lose a deal and then say. We're never inviting that guy back. He's a psycho. He doesn't get the deal, right? And so you have to learn, you know, how to behave, right? How to, how to build genuine rapport you know, and how to move things along. How to when to, when to sort of push forward and when to step back, right?

And and build in systems and processes for yourself that allow you to make sure your time's not being wasted and you're making the right investments at the right time. So that's kind of my, [00:11:00] my little, I explain it very well. Yeah. 

Henry Harrison: Yeah. I mean, I, if I were gonna summarize it I would say you're thinking about what the customer really wants and their needs first, because if you satisfy their needs, then you're gonna have a customer.

And if you can't, then 

Glenn Poulos: yeah, usually I wanna figure out, like I always sort of caution, like salespeople to take the time to look at how a customer really makes their money, right? Like, what does their business do and how does the money machine work in their business? Right? Because sometimes, you know and a simple example, you know, like just to show, what I mean by that is like I say, like maybe like Xerox photocopiers or whatever, right?

Everyone's like, wow, they sell photocopiers and printers, right? And I'm like, well, they lease photocopiers and printers. They're more of a finance company than they are a photocopier company, right? Like the photocopier's secondary to the way they make their money, which is on long-term financing deals. So they operate more like a bank than they do like a technology company.

And [00:12:00] so when you're selling to a business, you wanna make sure, you know, you don't wanna be selling to, you know, a printer maker when you, when you're actually selling to a bank like their money, their, their, their needs are different, right? And depending upon the, what you're selling, software, hardware, solutions, services, whatever.

You wanna make sure you know, the kind of problems they're gonna want to be solving, then you want to go another step further with them and you wanna say, Hey, like knowing that this is how they make their money, then this is probably the problem that they need to solve of the problems that we solve in our business.

And if they, we solve those problems for them, this is how they would feel. And if I could show them feeling that way, then they would ask me how to buy my product. And that's the key to selling, right? Is figure out what is it they really need to accomplish. How are they gonna feel when it's being done in a, a way that they've never done it that well before?

Like producing more widgets, lowering their costs, you know, higher throughput, more customers, you know, less churn, whatever. Whatever product or service you sell, right? And [00:13:00] then show them an example and show them how they're going to feel by implementing your product, service, or solution. And that's really what resonates with them is how they're gonna feel.

And it's like why they put it, you know, why they take a guy and they put him in the Corvette and let him take a test drive? Because they need him to feel what it's like to drive the Corvette. So they want to, so that it breaks down the barriers to him wanting to buy it. 

Henry Harrison: It helps you.

You mentioned you're such a professional, you're gonna have some somewhere I saw some listed questions that you'd like to be asked when you go on a podcast here and there. Do what's a good story about how you helped someone that was in your career, you know, particular sales story where it was a big home run for everybody or just a big business?

Glenn Poulos: Yeah, the okay. And I'm not, yeah, and I might have, I might have listed a few examples there. I'm not sure which one you're referring to, but I mean, one of my biggest ones was the, in the, the, the greatest story I have is the, the story of the Dofasco steel mill in Hamilton, Ontario, where I [00:14:00] was still learning the ropes, but I was, you know, very good at the products.

I knew them really well. Kind of a geeky, kind of a, you know, 20 something kid selling these products. And I knew them, knew them well and love, I love selling them. And I was out on a call with the president of the company that I worked for at the time, and we were calling on Dofasco in Hamilton.

They were putting in a new cold mill and Toshiba was the manufacturer of the mill equipment. So they were on site with a team, you know, putting in this giant mill, you know, you can imagine what it takes to put in a new steel mill, right? And and we, they were looking at equipment to measure and monitor signals and flow and all the things that would go on in producing steel, which I knew nothing about. I only knew how to measure signals. I didn't know anything about making steel. And so we, we showed up you know, it was a general sales call. We realized that these guys were gonna be buying a huge quantity of equipment for this mill, and none of it was ours.

And none of it was the way we were doing it. They were doing it the old way with a bunch of analog [00:15:00] meters and measurement systems. You know, think about it, I was offering a digital system, you know, with displays and numbers and what have you, and they were looking at dials and knobs and, you know, and pens and red ink, you know, scrolling down a paper tape, right?

They were still, they were still literally looking at analog strip chart solutions and things like that. Right. And I was able to show the, the, you know, this, this technician, we were calling on the you know, how much better our solution would work in this, right? And he says to me, he said, that's great, but you know, I can't, I can't change the way this, you know, this is all designed by Toshiba.

You know, you'd need to talk to Toshiba about that. I'm like, the president immediately said, well, where's Toshiba? Are they in Japan? And he's like, well, no, they're in town. Like, and like, okay, well where are they? And then he said, well, they're, you know, one town over, they have an office in Mississauga near the airport.

And he's like, okay, well, who's in charge? What's the guy's name? And gimme their address, what's his name? And the guy gave us the address and gave us the name. And, and he said, [00:16:00] Glenn, get in your car. We're going to Mississauga. And so we, we, you know, and of course this guy's, you know, like 30 years older than me and I'm the 20 something kid, right?

So I'm just doing what I'm said, but kind of watching and listening. I mean, my inclination would've been to go back and try to make an appointment with the guy at Toshiba and see if I could see him at some point that week, or he is like, no, we're driving there now. We're gonna bang on the door. Right. So we drive to Toshiba bang on the door, and lo and behold, the guy's there and we talk to him.

And, and we of course, you know, just to make a long story a little shorter, right? Like, we showed him the thing and he agreed, yeah, this is, this is very cool, he said, but you sell electrical stuff. And all the electrical stuff for the cold mill is designed in and sold and serviced and delivered by Guillevin International, one of the world's largest electrical distributors and, anything that's electrical plugs in or has a signal running through it has to be delivered supplied, tested and furnished by Guillevin. And he's like, okay, where are they? Who's in charge and what's their address? Lo and behold, we got the name and number of [00:17:00] a guy over near the airport. Said, Glenn, get your car.

We're going to see the guys at Guillevin. And so again, you can imagine we knocked on the door, the Guillevin guy, da da da. Interesting. He didn't really care. He just, you know, he said, well, if Toshiba wants it and Dofasco wants it, then I, then I don't really care. But he said like, any of these things that need changes need to be signed off by the vice president of Dofasco back at the steel mill in Hamilton.

Right. And we're like, well, okay, well who's the vice president and where's he working? And you know, where is he in, in the plant, right? And, and so it wasn't that that day, it was the next day, but the next day we got back in our car and we drove back to Hamilton to meet with the vice president and explained to him why our solution for digital monitoring of the signals was the better thing.

And I ended up getting an order for the largest order of my career ever. It was in more than my entire quota for the entire year in one order. And we did it all in a matter of 24 hours, having never not sent a single, email, fax, quote. You know, we didn't [00:18:00] mail anything, ship anything, deliver anything. It was all done in real time.

And it showed me the power of, like, when people say, oh, I left him a voicemail, and I call him back, I'm gonna make an appointment. No. Like you, you know, if you're in a building and the guy says, well, I like what I'm seeing, but my boss needs to, you know, to weigh in on it. It was like, okay, great. Can you introduce me to your boss now?

And, that's the difference between the really good salespeople and then the, and the out and the also ands, right? They never know. You know, they're the, they're the ones, when you ask them what's going on with the deal, they say, oh, they sent it upstairs to the powers that be right. And I'm like, who's the powers that be okay?

And they're like, I don't know. No one knows. And I'm like, okay, well you're not getting the order. Because the guy who's getting the order knows the powers that be because he's talked to 'em already and made sure that we're within spec, within budget, within, you know tolerances within whatever.

And he's covered off the whole scope of people that are [00:19:00] required based on the purchase level that's happening. If it's a $5,000 item, it might only be one or two guys, but if it's a $500,000 purchase, the CEO's probably signing off on it. Right. And so you need to figure all that out upfront and make sure you know, you need to start and sort of finish at the highest possible level relative to the size of the deal that you're selling. In other words, you don't wanna take a $500 you know, printer, for instance, to the CEO and say, oh, I wanna get your impression on this. But if it's a $500,000, 50 ton stamping machine for a auto plant you can bet that the top guys in the plant are signing off on that, that equipment.

So you wanna start with those guys and get them to push you down so that you can always go back and check in on where you sit in the in the food chain of the, of the deal. Are you winning, losing, you know what's required to make this deal happen? Because a lot of times they'll tell you, Hey, you're not getting the order 'cause we don't like your product, we don't like your company. Or we, we have a contract with a different company, or we're doing it through this [00:20:00] financing and they'll only deal with XY and you don't qualify and you're not this, and you're like, oh, that's not fair. And it's like too bad. Like those are all the reasons why you often lose and never know.

But if you're talking to the big guys, they just tell you up front like, you know, you need a license or you need this or you need that and you don't have this. And, and you can, you know, but you're not gonna get that guy from the guy on the shop floor. He is gonna say, oh, whatever the powers that be, say.

It's beyond my pay grade. 

Henry Harrison: That was a good story and a lot of lessons there. What are, what's another story of maybe a a difficult time that you had that you overcome because anybody that's accomplished something is had a ear failure or a 

Glenn Poulos: Okay, I got a good one time, 

Henry Harrison: or, yeah, 

Glenn Poulos: so my first business.

That was, you know, targeting the, the cellular industry, right? The, the cellular network industry. I sold it after 15 years and it was a life-changing amount of money. I, I sold it to a public company and I got millions of dollars worth of shares in their public company. This was a [00:21:00] household name in Canada.

Anyone would've known them. And just to make a long story short I didn't do any due diligence on them. 'cause I. I knew who they were, right? They sold cell phones. They were in the malls. You know, I knew exactly who they were. I knew the, the, the president the CEO guy was sort of like, you know infamous in some ways for his, you know, crazy business shenanigans and whatever that he'd done and deals he's done.

And he'd been around a long time and they offered you know, millions of dollars in shares, but no cash for the deal. Very little cash. And what I didn't realize was that their business, they had had tentacles out into all sorts of areas that was draining cash from their corporate pools, you know, faster than you can imagine.

And they saw how much cash our business was throwing off and they saw that this could be a part solution to some of their problems. And they ended up buying our business for stock. I became an insider, couldn't sell my stock. Within 18 months, they bankrupted both my company and their company, [00:22:00] and all of us lost our jobs.

And I ended up having given them a company, I'd been spent 15 years building for free, and I got nothing. Then I was 40 something years old with kids and, you know and what have you. And and of course I, I had nothing left. I went from multimillionaire on paper to broke ass, right. One fell swoop.

I had no idea that it was coming. I wasn't at the C-suite. I work in the operating division. But they ended up putting our company into receivership and then they went into receivership and bankruptcy and the shares became worthless. And I didn't get a penny out of it, which is why I started Gap Wireless and because I needed a job.

For me, it was easier to start a new company than it was to apply for a job. And and people are like, well, how in the world did you bounce back from it? And I'm like, well, I didn't have time to bounce back. I, I just had to like, go and get a job, like, you know, and so I didn't have time to like fret and moan and, you know, and cry over it.

And, and there are people like, well, I never could have done that. And, [00:23:00] you know, and other people struggled. There were two other partners that struggled with what the way it had gone down and, you know but I basically within days I had already taken money outta my retirement savings and had started the funding for Gap Wireless, which grew from a million dollars in sales its first year to 84 million the year I sold it. And and so, you know, out of the ashes, right? But, you know, here I was, I thought I was this multimillionaire in the early two thousands and I was broke and I had nothing actually. And the worst part was that, you know, when people said, well, you gave away your company, and I did.

So when I sold Gap Wireless, I sold it for cash of course. Right. I didn't take any shares. Right. So yeah. 

Henry Harrison: Wow. Well, congratulations. Yeah. You have a can do. Go get it. Get up in the morning, put your pants on attitude. It's nice to see. It's inspiring. What clients do you have now are the,

Glenn Poulos: so the, the customers we deal with now are mainly with what are called IOUs, investor [00:24:00] owned utilities are our biggest customers, but it's wherever you're driving down the road and you see a giant power plant with all the transformers and you know, all those little round things and things shooting out of them and you know, the green things and whatever. They're basically circuit breakers and transformers and battery banks and insulators.

And we sell equipment to test all that stuff. So that's called the substation, where you see all that stuff coming down into these, you know, fenced in pens and things and, and so any utility that's generating or distributing electricity, you know is our customer. And that's the big ones.

You know, like Duke Energy and Florida Light and, you know Pacific Gas these are our biggest customers. And they buy equipment to test the transformers, the breakers, the battery banks. They test for, you know, and there's, you know, we sell thermal cameras and other kinds of camera products for, analyzing any problems with the lines and things like that. And so yeah, that's, that's what I'm doing now. [00:25:00] 

Henry Harrison: That's pretty cool. And those are big customers, I imagine they're gonna be needing what you sell for a long, long time. My dad retired at 79 for health reasons, didn't want to and, went on to live happily for significant time afterwards, but he enjoyed his work. I can see you're passionate, you enjoy your work, and you like adding value, creating, making money, all those things for your family. How long, what's, what's the look like ahead now? Just gonna keep going and growing for another 84 million a year revenue business, or, yeah, 

Glenn Poulos: I don't think, I don't know if I'll get that long.

That took you know 15 years to get to, and I mean, I'm 63, so I'm not sure I'll quite get to the map. I don't know if it'll work out Right. But you know. I, I'd like to see where I can get this. This company I bought by myself though, the last company, I had a partner, the one before, I had two partners.

So this one is also sort of a personal goal to see what I can do in, you know, over the next three to five years by myself. You know I. Whatever I can leverage or [00:26:00] however I can you know network my company in other whatever ways it means to grow. And but knowing that I kind of had to resolve to, to my own devices to get it done right.

And so it's a little bit of an internal challenge that I'm doing, but you know. I'd probably like to quiet down in, you know, three to five years economy, depending, you know, like right now the economy's kind of weird, wonky but I do believe that the power grid will be receiving an, you know, a significant amount of funding and optimization in the coming years to feed all the data centers that are exploding because of ai.

Yeah. And so there's just an insatiable demand for power and more than we can even deliver. And so, you know, my little piece of what I, where I am, where I'm involved, I think should benefit and yeah. But, you know but I don't think I'll do it again for like a fourth time. You know, if I sold it in a few years, I'd probably, then I'll, you know, okay.

I'll maybe try to quiet down a little bit and just [00:27:00] relax. 

Henry Harrison: In your last company, in this company, do you have a, a lot of big staff or is it 

Glenn Poulos: The last company gap we grew up to, we grew to 80 people. But in 2019 we we had to, we had another like near death experience. We had branched off into areas of telecom that we didn't belong and we didn't know what we were doing and we started losing truckloads of money and we ended up going from 80 people to 29 people in one day and having to do a massive adjustment. And and so, but by the end, in 2022 when we sold it, we were in 43 people, I think. The company I bought has about 10 people. I think we're up to 13 now. So very small company, so the, the gap had grown grown to about 80, but had to shrink down to more, more reasonable 40, which is where it belonged, and get back in right size itself for financial health reasons.

But yeah, that's kind of the size of the companies that I'm dealing with. 

Henry Harrison: Right now, if people wanna [00:28:00] find out about your business, they wanna find out about you would you suggest they go to your website or 

Glenn Poulos: So if they wanna communicate to me and talk about, they can go to my website and connect with me there.

You know, there's a contact and everything. But LinkedIn's probably the better way to get ahold of me. I'm there every day. I'm a LinkedIn Top Voice. I'm posting every day lots of content and lots of interaction with people. You know, and they can easily connect with me and then communicate with me. Any questions, comments that they have. Happy to talk to anybody in that manner, but either the website or LinkedIn or the best, best ways. And what is the website? So everybody can, so it's just GlennPoulos.com. So my name dot com. Okay.

Henry Harrison: So you're growing another business. You're you're healthy, you got years ahead.

When you were a little kid, I'm just wondering if you ever thought you would own or start businesses because going to work for the government as you said is not the, oh. I mean, maybe it is in some cases, but a lot of people, that's not the path to right. And, and a lot of my [00:29:00] government, I grew up in Washington, DC a lot of my family was career government, so, and they had great contributions.

So I love people that work at the government. I have a special passion, obviously with this podcast, Entrepreneurs Business & Finance. Yeah, I, I like entrepreneurs and business owners because they create jobs and do a lot of good. But when you were a kid, was there anything that you can look back to and think, man, I thank goodness that boss told me, but I didn't know myself or, or I dreamed of doing it but didn't 'cause I got this job.

Or how, how did that go? 

Glenn Poulos: So, yeah, so funny. I was I was actually raised in a motel, so my parents owned a motel in Niagara Falls and I grew up servicing customers, cleaning rooms, cutting the grass, vacuuming the pool. It was a motel on Lundy Lane in Niagara Falls, Ontario, Canada, and it was very busy and very interesting, colorful childhood, and I got to interact with customers from a very young age. I got started getting paid by the hour by when I was eight or nine. And so I was [00:30:00] always working . But, but honestly, you know, and some people sort of look at me sideways when I say this, but I've always had this like, incredible fear of poverty that drives me forward to earn money at all.

Like, I just can't sit still. Right? And people are like, why? And I'm like, 'cause I'm afraid of being poor. Like, I don't, you know, like, and so that's why I started a business so quickly after losing the one before, right? I didn't have time to cry in my milk. I had to like, you know, and it's outta sheer and utter fear, right? And so I had always been chasing opportunities to make money. As a kid, I always had a job. And the government was the most, was a very lucrative position coming out of electronic school. I got a chance to work with them up in the Arctic and I was making three or four times what cohorts were making come outta school 'cause I had danger pay, isolation pay, you know, the government was paying well, you know, and so again, even though it was the government and you're like, okay, well, you know, I was still doing really well by it. And, and so I've always been sort of driven to, you [00:31:00] know, I call it like sort of poverty avoidance, right?

And and it, it naturally pushes me forward and gives me the, you know, the get up and go that I need, you know, to, to work every day. And it, it's a natural instinct. I don't have to like, you know, feed it or anything, it just comes, comes naturally, right? And you know, and so hopefully at the end I'll be able to let it go and relax for, you know, at, at some point.

But yeah, so I've always been, I've always been driven to you know to find wa ways and means to make money even as a young kid. So 

Henry Harrison: what, what drove you to get so involved in LinkedIn? Because top voice and all that, you are very engaged.

Glenn Poulos: Yeah. It, well, you know, just the, well one, I, you know, I wrote this book never sit in the lobby, you know, 57 tips on how to build a career in sales.

And and, you know, I do it to sort of just keep the buzz going around the, you know, they call it thought leadership and what have you around the messages that I have and the stories that I like to tell [00:32:00] and sort of, she used it to share podcasts that I'm on or stories from the book, you know, or other stories that are relevant just to try to keep the dialogue going, you know, 'cause otherwise it kind of, you know, you write a book, you publish it, and you go off into the sunset with 80 million other books.

Right? And and so, just, just for the, just to keep the whole dialogue going, which is why, why find LinkedIn to be the best place for that? And there's a lot of good conversations that get, that get going. But it's also challenging and, and hard work now too. Like it's not saying it was easier before, but I mean, but now it's kind of the, it's tough to get through the noise and, we've all seen how social media is evolving and so many ads and sponsored content and stuff like that, you really need to work to figure out how to message it so that it gets put out on the algorithm and customers, can read it. Right, 

Henry Harrison: right, right. Yeah. I think you have an entrepreneurial background with parents [00:33:00] being business owners, you know, that was, gave you some comfort or orientation to how that goes. And, and also the stress of what that means. 'Cause the paycheck doesn't just come unless no, 

Glenn Poulos: yeah. Unless 

Henry Harrison: the hotel performs. Just circle back on that. I, I usually ask people this because it's just a part of everyday consideration now, and you actually have listed on your LinkedIn profile, but AI and growth expert, 

Glenn Poulos: yeah, so I use, I use AI everywhere I possibly can. I've been playing around with some, a little bit of consulting about trying to help customers to adapt AI. But over the last six months or so, my other business has gotten very busy, so I have to have to sort of divide my time smartly.

But, but I'm using AI to, you know, to help me to look for more opportunities to quote our equipment, like to, to, to research. You know, bidding sites, government sites utility sites to find, because like it's very hard to find every opportunity out there with a small group of people in a [00:34:00] business.

And so now there's ways of getting AI to data mine for you. And then you get these tenders and things for to quote, and it can take a week or two to respond to 'em using ai interpretation to go through these long tenders and figure out all the relevant points that I need to complete. And then, you know, and then using, using my past sort of submissions and offers that I've done.

Pull from that to help me to do a lot of the legwork that you used to have to do manually. And also coming up with marketing ideas, coming up with you know, text campaigns and things you know, to share with customers. It's super powerful looking at contracts and complicated purchase documents from large corporations.

They have like 80 page terms and I'm like, I can't read that. Like, I'll never get through it, right? But you can put that in AI and, and say, oh, well do you, you know, it says you need 10 million of insurance. And it says, you know, indemnification of this, that, and the other thing, and a warranty for, you know, and it quickly isolates the points you need to get to, and the rest [00:35:00] is boilerplate, right?

So I'm using AI in every possible turn, however possible I can. But of course, I'm not using it blindly. I'm not just saying, Hey, write me an email, cutting and pasting it, sending it to thousands of customers. It's, you know, it's, give me an idea, what are some key points, you know, and then using it to help me craft something and then humanizing it and then, you know, sending it kind of thing.

And yeah, so I used it all aspects of the business. Also in the finance department, looking at the financials and helping me with cash flow and, you know is the health of the company improving or disproving or what, you know, whatever over time. And it's just so capable. It's, it's incredible the tool that it's become for, for business owners.

Henry Harrison: Yeah. It, it absolutely is. And you we'll wrap up, personally you have a big family you mentioned and you have some hobbies you enjoy. You're in a beautiful part of the world.

Glenn Poulos: I have I have five kids. It's a blended family, but five kids. I have my [00:36:00] wife. We, we live half in Florida business and half in Canada.

I'm a little bit more in Florida. My wife's probably a little bit more up in Canada. We have two French Bulldogs, which we love greatly. And it's a big part of our lives. And play pickleball. We, you know, we have a place up on the Blue Mountain in the ski slopes in Canada, and we're in Orlando and Florida.

So, yeah, so things are good and you know, the market's tough right now, but you know, you just have to press on every day, show up every day, get up, go to work, and you know, and time marches on and you know. It's, you know, you never know what to expect tomorrow, but you know, you gotta show up for it.

Right. So, 

Henry Harrison: absolutely. Well, you're definitely showing up. I admire all your accomplishments. I appreciate you coming on the, the show the Henry Harrison podcast, Entrepreneurs Business and Finance. And you can find Glenn Poulos on on his website, which is GlennPoulos.com. You can also look him up on LinkedIn where he is a great [00:37:00] contributor.

And I don't know if there's anything else you'd like to wrap up. I've no. Good you a while and I think the audience is gonna love it.

In this episode, we delve into the art of selling without the typical sales pitch, exploring how to navigate business acquisitions under non-compete agreements. Glenn Poulos shares his journey of pivoting industries from telecom to power utilities, and how he bounced back from a major financial setback to achieve remarkable success. We also discuss the strategic use of AI in enhancing sales processes and securing enterprise deals.

Glenn's candid insights reveal the importance of understanding customer revenue models and building customer-first systems that ensure long-term success. His story of transforming a zero-value exit into a thriving business venture is a testament to resilience and strategic thinking. Tune in to learn practical strategies for leveraging AI in sales and the importance of high-level engagement in enterprise negotiations.

podcasts.guestBio: Glenn Poulos is currently the founder and CEO of Prog USA and co-founder of GAP Wireless (sold to PE), LinkedIn Top Voice, and author of *Never Sit in the Lobby*, known for AI-driven, enterprise sales leadership.

header_6_font_size_phone="13px" header_6_font_size_last_edited="on|desktop" global_colors_info="{}"]Burt Copeland's entrepreneurial journey began with a construction company that he grew from $7 million to a $30 million run rate. However, the financial crisis of 2008 led to a significant loss, prompting a pivotal shift in his career. This experience inspired Burt to establish New Life CFO, with a mission to guide other entrepreneurs away from similar pitfalls. At New Life CFO, Burt leverages his hard-earned insights to provide strategic financial leadership, focusing on sustainable growth and value creation for businesses.[/et_pb_text][et_pb_video src="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=McrjpKBnBDw" image_src="https://henryharrison.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/Burt-Copeland-on-Henry-Harrison-Podcast.jpg" module_id="burt" _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="default" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_video][et_pb_code _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="default" global_colors_info="{}"]
