Henry Harrison Podcast Burt Copeland

Henry Harrison: [00:00:00] I'm very glad to have the CEO owner, and founder of New Life CFO on the Henry Harrison podcast today, Entrepreneurs Business and Finance. We become friends. I've seen him speak. We collaborated about how he can help my company and he's a a terrific guy. So, hello, Burt Copeland.

Burt Copeland: Henry, thanks a ton for letting me be on your podcast. It's great to have you back in the building. It was a, a warm surprise to see your face wandering around through the lobby a couple of weeks ago. So welcome back. 

Henry Harrison: Well, you have a pretty neat company and you have a team of at least 16 people last time I checked, the name explains a little bit New Life CFO, but I know you can do it better than than I can. So what do you do? What does your company do? 

Burt Copeland: You know, we are outsourced, CFO and some outsourced accounting services. So fractional CFO is the term that a lot of people are familiar with.

So about two thirds of the company [00:01:00] is outsourced CFO, and about one third of the company is outsourced accounting services and really controller, assisted controller and accounting managers. So. On one side, we're doing the strategy, and on the other side we're making sure the books are ready for people to make great decisions from 'cause what we've found over the years is even a great CFO cannot make good decisions on bad information. So that's always our starting point. 

Henry Harrison: Well, it is, it is really important because to being involved in the Entrepreneurs Organization, there's a lot of small businesses that are doing a lot of big business, but they don't necessarily have the budget to bring in, especially when they're in the early stages, and then maybe even later bring in someone full-time as a CFO that would require pretty high salary and bonus and all that, but they really need those services. So you may work for some quite large companies as well, but I know well, what is the range of companies you work with?

Burt Copeland: Great question on, on the [00:02:00] accounting side, it's as low as a million or two all the way up to about 25 million. On the CFO side, we have gone as low as a couple of million, but it's generally a starting point of about 5 million, up to about 80 million. There needs to be enough critical mass so that we are not overhead.

I, I tell my clients all the time, Hey, as soon as I start to look like overhead, you need to fire me. 'cause I should be absolutely a great investment for driving performance, cash flow and ebitda. And as soon as that stops, man, you need to kick me to the curb because that's really the role of A CFO is changing the dynamics and sustainable performance of a company.

Henry Harrison: And when you're talking about CFO services, I noticed on your website there's quite a range that goes with that because you're in their business and the most, well, one of the most important parts is, is you can't really do much if you don't have control of your numbers and you can't plan for capital raises, you can't plan to manage your [00:03:00] accounting.

You can't plan for evaluation to see if you wanna do a capital raise. So. I, I'm just imagining that's part of why you end up doing a lot of those other things because you're there and you've got the expertise and they say, Hey, Burt, can you help with this, help with that, or, or one of your team members do that for you and for them?

Burt Copeland: No, you're exactly right on. And what we found over the time is, you know, entrepreneur, it's a very unique beast in the world and they're usually outstanding at product, outstanding at technical service, or really outstanding in business development and market management. But number management is not their forte, you know, and, and we've all been given different gifts in our lives.

And what we find too often is the entrepreneur doesn't really understand what their numbers are telling them about their business, and more importantly, doesn't understand the actions they should take to change their business based upon what the numbers are telling. And we have one saying here at New Life, it's like your financials are nothing but a historical reflection of your [00:04:00] people, decisions, behaviors, processes, and systems. Therefore, irrespective of your strategy, if you really want to change your numbers, you have to step back and, and see what your numbers are telling you about where to change your people, their decisions, behaviors, processes, and systems.

When you get those things aligned and you build a better infrastructure, then you build a better platform for sustainable, improving profitability. 

Henry Harrison: The CEO of and now he's he may still be CEO, but he stepped down and going on to become a professor Chris McKee. 

Burt Copeland: Oh yeah. Great guy. Great guy.

Yeah. 

Henry Harrison: Venturity and really smart guy, obviously. And it's one of the largest outsourced, maybe the largest financial accounting companies in, in, certainly in Dallas, probably in DFW, maybe in Texas. But and he told a story about how it, the company. I'm gonna ask, I'm gonna, I asked him a question I'm gonna ask you is, what are some obstacles you overcame?

And he said, well, how about the time I almost ran our [00:05:00] company into the ground for cash flow. He said, that's a fun story that goes around the company. But basically he was short, he was overly optimistic about their expansion and didn't manage his cash well, well enough. And all of a sudden he was worried about payroll.

And so,

Burt Copeland: yeah, 

Henry Harrison: I know you have some stories like that with your clients. 

Burt Copeland: Oh, and, and Chris is a good dude, and, and they are a great firm. So great people, great firm. You know, my personal story relates to how I even started this company, so I'm gonna roll the picture back here a little bit to really my entire career has been in financial management, from public accounting to start out with various roles in strategic planning, controllership and CFOs.

And in 2000 I was the CFO of a $65 million construction company. And a couple years into that I was promoted to president of that company and a few more years into that I actually bought the North Texas operations from the parent. That was about seven out of the 65 million, and we are a high service [00:06:00] commercial subcontractor to commercial buildings and major GCs.

And in very short period of time, we had grown from the 7 million to a run rate of 30 million, and that run rate year was 2008. And so my story goes in, in March of 2008 my revenues literally went from a little bit around 2.2 million in April, there were $325,000. It was 86% drop in revenues in one month May was 375,000.

And what happened is the banks shut down all construction until they could "Assess the value of the underlying collateral." And so my business just stopped hard and because we had built it up. I had employees doing installation 'cause to me that was a part of our service delivery commitment. But the problem was, is my break even point was well over $800,000.

So I was losing, losing half a [00:07:00] million hard every month for three months before they turned back on. And that sent me into total panic. You talk about Chris running outta outta cash, man, I was out of everything I really had, I'll, I'll be very honest with you, I had a faith epiphany as well as a business epiphany and my observations ultimately, I had great staff and experience back in the day of doing turnarounds, and we got the company turned around, but I lost a fortune in 2008. I mean, probably net worth and everything else, six to 7 million 2009 was my best year ever. But my epiphany, both personal business and faith, was this, holy smokes man, if I can step in this bear trap and barely get out alive what about the average entrepreneur? And so I became very passionate about, you know, my calling was to go out and serve entrepreneurs to make sure that they don't step in that same bear trap and lose everything. [00:08:00] So I rebuilt my company. I sold it off to a fantastic strategic partner here in this marketplace.

Transitioned it, and I didn't even know what a fractional CFO was. I was literally going out, knocking on doors, was like, Hey, could you use a really good CFO? That's also run its own company. From that comes from that is this concept of operational CFOs. So if you looked at the portfolio of our CFOs, they all have some level of operating experience in addition to CFO.

So they've been a general manager, a division leader, A COO, and a couple of us have owned our own companies. What we've found is having sat on that other side of the desk. We know what it's like to manage through all those other functional areas so they become a bigger part of sustainable performance.

The other thing that we look for though, is CFOs that have stubbed their toe professionally somewhere in their past. 'cause to know what a sleepless [00:09:00] night really feels like makes us a much better empathetic partner. And let's just face it, arrogance with financial, you know, intelligence doesn't really come off all that well.

So having a little humility as we go into that marketplace is it helps to develop great relationships with the CEO on a trusting relationship, which, which most people really need on their financial world. And hopefully that makes sense. 

Henry Harrison: Makes a lot of sense. Yeah, and I think I bet your clients do like the fact that your team has a by and large, a large bit of experience in the world of actually owning a business. When I was a home builder, I, we had a really good consultant that we used to go to and he was rare 'cause he hadn't had that experience himself. But a lot of the, he was kind of the go-to for the home builders around the country. But he had a lot of people on his team that that did.

And you also have a vast perspective if, if it's one CFO in one company they may, you know, they may have a network of people that they talk to like [00:10:00] entrepreneurs or what other CFOs, but. You were seeing so many and that was advantage of this consultant for the home building. He saw so many home buildings, he always had stories.

Well, let me tell you what this company did in this situation. Oh yeah. Lemme tell you how that worked out. You've got so many of those, much more than if you just had your own company. 'cause then you just have your one story. 

Burt Copeland: Well, and then you can take all those lessons that you accumulate over the years, or even from our other CFOs and you can start putting those.

Together into a much richer toolbox to solve people's problems. You know, one of the things that I did with one client my background's in construction, so I kind of know where profit leaks in construction or in professional services that are project-based companies. So I was working with this software company and they had 50 programmers and technical installers and all this other stuff, and I was working with them and it's like, okay, well your profitability is about one third of where it's supposed to be. They're about [00:11:00] 3.5%. They should have been real close to 10. Maybe 10 plus. And so I asked these four very harsh questions.

I asked 'em, okay, so something is working well below average 'cause you're one third of average, not one third of great, you're one third of average. And so I asked them, okay, is your product in services that you sell every day? Are those well below average? Nope. Are the people that you hire, vet, train, and deploy to your clients?

Are those well below average? No. We have great people says, okay. The third one's a really hard question. Is this leadership team well below average? No. We have great people. It's like fantastic, because the fourth question, and there's only four, is that means that your processes for executing have to be well below average, and we need to go find out where they're broken.

What we did very quickly, shortly thereafter, is we brought everybody together and I, I had this chart that I use about where [00:12:00] profit leaks and those kind of things, and we give everybody in the company sales. Each person's sales got three dots, sticky dots of one color accounting, got a separate color.

The operations people got a third color and the estimators got a fourth color. And I asked them, y'all go up there in this chart that had, I don't know 35 different options about profit leakage. And I says, I want you to put your dot on the three that you think are the most important or the most obvious.

And what's incredible is we quickly honed in on that they were missing change orders all over the place. And so I asked the questions like, okay. For, for you technicians, how much time do you spend a week that could have been a change order, but you step over it because it's it's only a few hours? All of them raise their hand.

I said, well, how many hours is that? They agreed that on average it's two hours a week, and I go, well, how often does that happen? Every week. So now we're talking about a hundred hours a week, times 50 weeks at a bill [00:13:00] rate of 250 to $300 an hour. Now the deal on that is because they've paid for a hundred percent of the cost of executing all those incremental dollars dropped a hundred percent to the bottom line.

So within a very short period of time, they had more than doubled their profitability by changing that one process. And that's where we get into changing what your people do and their behaviors is critical, but you have to have a financial filter about where to go make those changes. 

Henry Harrison: That you and I talked about briefly is projections.

That's a difficult thing for entrepreneurs to do, but it's so important is they decide whether to hire, unfortunately, maybe lay off or, or invest in a new venture or and that's probably a weakness as well. Do you have some stories or process for that? 

Burt Copeland: It can be because you know, to, to quote Greenspan too often we will hire on [00:14:00] irrational exuberance and not the reality of the situation.

So just as a teaser for everybody out there, one of my favorite metrics in the world, and we use it on every client, is revenue per head. 'cause revenue per head gives me a good benchmark about my number one cost structure, which is generally my people and my revenue. And let's just say for kicks and giggles here that my average revenue per head is $25,000 per month.

Well, if it starts hitting 27 and 28, my people are starting to get stressed because they're probably working overtime. And so that's a trigger that I need to start my hiring process because by the time it gets to be 30 or 32, I'm burning them up. So you can use it as a trigger that says, this is what I need to start my hiring process, and this is what I hope to have 'em to modulate that back down to $25,000 per head.

Now I can use it on the same exact opposite to where if my revenue per head starts going from 25 down to 23, down to 22, [00:15:00] I need to let attrition start taking its, you know, magic hand on my company or possibly doing layoffs. But there's another really important thing. You talked about projections and just total business projections.

Where people get hung up is they, they get hung up on precision over utility. And so what we will do is, because nobody's gonna nail a projection perfectly, so let's say that you're starting out a new location, a new salesperson or a new business line, and here's what all you generally ask like. I, I used to use this on my salespeople when I interviewed 'em, so that's where this comes from.

I'd say, Henry, you've been in this industry for a long time. You, you know what this looks like. You're gonna be a great partner here at Company X. Henry, can you tell me what you think your aggregate bookings are gonna be on 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18 months as we go out? That's fantastic. Henry, you hit those numbers buddy.

We are gonna be friends for life. But Henry, [00:16:00] can you tell me on the exact same timeline what you consider the lowest level of acceptable performance for yourself on 3, 6, 9, 12? Right? And if you plot out those two lines, you're gonna end up with a cone of performance. And so what I tell my sales prospects, my salespeople, prospects, like, I don't expect you to be on the top line right away.

And as long as you're heading towards that top line. That's great, but as soon as you're, because I had this cone of performance that we just mapped out, but as soon as your performance line starts to flat line relative to those other two curves or starts to head down, something's not working.

Something's broken as a signal and we need to pivot. The same thing holds true for a business and doing your projections. It's not the absolute number. It's stress testing your numbers to find out an acceptable range of performance and knowing what success looks like. And what the lack of success looks like so you can pivot early and correct early. [00:17:00] Terrific. Terrific. 

Henry Harrison: Talk a little bit about just even the name of your company. It's an interesting name, you know, and you talk about the epiphany and the struggle and the change of, of losing. I mean, I guess you didn't lose your company in the end, but you almost lost it and you lost a lot and then you went a different direction.

I know there was a lot of passion behind that. There had to be, 

Burt Copeland: so a lot of the name of New Life, and I'll share a little bit of the faith experience that I went through in there. So it's a combination of faith, experience, and accountability that this should never become the Burt Show. Now I'm the face of the marketplace, but if my ego gets in the way of, of making sure my customers are taken care of, that's the wrong answer.

So a part of the faith experience when I was on near collapse I had two prayers that I prayed a lot. I was in total panic buddy. Like I thought I was gonna lose everything. Had no idea what I was gonna do next. My credibility was gonna be ruined. [00:18:00] I didn't know if I could even get a job. I seriously considered going back and mowing lawns as a kid if this thing collapsed, it was that bad.

But my faith epiphany, I used to run a lot. Clearly, I, I don't anymore, but I was out on a morning run and my two prayers is, well, what is it you want me to learn from this experience? And where do you want me to go? Because I was broken and lost, and I'm telling you whether you call me insane or not. On that first prayer, what do you want me to learn from it?

I had a voice that came to me and says, you're not using my gifts that I gave you, and you left me behind. Wow. So you can start to see where new life starts to come into that, as far as a new direction and everything else. And I immediately started changing how I, how I was managing my company at that point in time.

And then I kept on praying about, that's fantastic. I feel so much better. The lesson learned. I, I totally resonate that, but I'm still lacking. Where do you want me to go? 'cause I'm lost. I [00:19:00] have no clue what's next. That answer was simply came back again. Same voice says, use my gifts and take me with you.

And it's from that, that ultimately it's like, okay, I can't do that calling inside my construction company, which really led to me to sell it and to go use those gifts and go serve others in a God honoring way. In fact, if you looked at my website on the mission statement, it says to use our God giving gifts.

To go and serve others in a God-honoring way and to proactively engage our clients in a Care-Frontational manner to make sure that their goals and objectives are achieved. We say Care-Frontational because we're there to push. We're, we're not there to be yes. So it's okay if you prove us wrong in the conversation.

It's just not okay to avoid that conversation. So hopefully I didn't get too deep for you, but that's exactly where the name comes from. It's a calling and then it's accountability [00:20:00] statement. 

Henry Harrison: No, thank you for sharing. Thank you for sharing. And I actually went to SMU Cox Business School, got an MBAI went at night.

I was just looking down. You were at A&M and then was that the business school?

Burt Copeland: Full time. I actually graduated from East Texas State and it's now East Texas A&M, but I too got my grad degree from SMU got out in 96. So When did you get out? I was at night as well. 'cause I, I liked my paycheck buddy.

Henry Harrison: Yeah, I we were there at the same time. 

Burt Copeland: We were. That's so crazy. Was there in 

Henry Harrison: nine, seven? 

Burt Copeland: Wow. 

Henry Harrison: I graduated in nine seven. It was the part-time program, right? Yeah. And it was three it was a, they didn't shorten it either, so it was the whole full-time MBA, you know, two, it was just over a longer period of time.

Yeah. It was one of the 

Burt Copeland: best experiences ever for me. It changed my career. 

Henry Harrison: I, I felt like I had a limited vantage point 'cause I went to work for home building and then I was in home building. That really helped me expand my horizons. My [00:21:00] family was professionals, lawyers, doctors, so, and the Entrepreneurs Organization helped a lot.

You know, who was there as well at that time was de Deanna Walker, who's at Venturity. 

Burt Copeland: Yeah. I didn't know that. I'll have to Yeah. Raise that flag next time I see her. She too is a great person. 

Henry Harrison: Well, so that changed your career? Yeah. And how, how did it change your career? Just getting a broader perspective and learning the tools.

Burt Copeland: Oh. You know, as well versed in being a CPA and I was already A CFO, but it really got me into the operational side. This is where money is really made. 'cause you know, a CFO can manage cash flow and capital structure, but it's hard for A CFO to change profitability 'cause that happens in the selling process, and that happens in the operational process.

Having really good insight into those other functionalities. That's where it was life changing for me. You could literally see how the different parts of the machine should work together to optimize the company, whether it's profitability, cash, or enterprise [00:22:00] value. It was fantastic experience and, and between you and I, I'm glad I did it when we did it 'cause it's a hell of a lot more expensive now.

Henry Harrison: Yeah, I guess I haven't followed that. And so when you were a kid are you from Texas originally? Both Texas schools 

Burt Copeland: born and raised. I've lived in Dallas 62 outta my 65 years. 

Henry Harrison: Okay. And what were you, what were you like as a kid? Were you thinking about entrepreneurial things because you started, well, at least two businesses and were you, or what, what was your.

Family orientation, go get a job 

Burt Copeland: for life. Oh, no. As, as a kid literally my goal as a kid, I wanted to be a thoracic surgeon. I wanted to be a heart surgeon all my life. I wanted to be a heart surgeon. And then I was at A&M proper. And I was in the core, loved the core. That was so much fun. But my grades were like a three too.

I was like, Nope, I'm not gonna be a surgeon being a three, two. And, and I got outta the core to improve my grades. [00:23:00] Didn't really have the same vig for A&M and ultimately through family relationships. I knew a bunch of people that were partners in CPA firms. I was always good at math and that just led me to like, maybe I need to explore that.

And a year later I changed my degree plan from a lifelong desire of wanting to be a surgeon to wanting to be a CPA. That's some pluses and minuses. I joke around that my first three years in public accounting, I was there five years, were in audit, and I describe audit as being skinned alive with a butter knife.

I hated it. It was awful. But I learned a ton about what great accounting is supposed to look like, and then I pivoted over into doing bankruptcies, workouts, reorgs. All that other turnarounds as far as in Coopers & Lybrand. That was great work. That also was a huge pivot in my life. But public accounting was great.

I'm glad I didn't stay in audit though. 

Henry Harrison: My brother he went [00:24:00] to the Mayo Clinic, he academic Dean of the Mayo Clinic and valedictorian. Wow. And I was a good student. I went to Emory University and I did well, but also I thought, you know, I'm not that studious. I'd be better off something in business.

My dad was a lawyer. He, I think he went to, I'm sure he did. He, he went to Stanford when he was 16. And so everybody's very, very studious. And it's like, I was studious, but some people thought I was studious. But compared to my family and my grandfather was a PhD, I was like, no, I, I'm, but I had a hard time knowing exactly what to do.

So I went into home building 'cause I liked that they were building things. I can see. So I identify with your con love for construction. 

Burt Copeland: Oh yeah. It's, it's, it is very gratifying to go out to a job site and see how it's completed. See that it's built to drive by buildings, go, oh, I was a part of that right there.

Henry Harrison: Yeah, that 

Burt Copeland: is a good feeling. 

Henry Harrison: Did you have things that you started when you were a kid or you were too busy thinking about being a a surgeon? 

Burt Copeland: No, I, I worked most of my life. Again, I mentioned mowing [00:25:00] lawns. So I mowed lawns, painted houses installed sprinkler systems. In fact. I didn't have an inside.

I had one inside job as a kid, and that was for about two months working at a McDonald's. And there's only so long ago smelling like grease that you want to have that job. And let's face it, I made a ton of money doing the other stuff. In fact, the first year as a CPA actually made more money the previous year painting houses and mowing lawns than I did my first year in Coopers & Lybrand.

Henry Harrison: I remember I mow lawns as well and it your for a teenager is when I did it, it sure was a lot of money. 

Burt Copeland: Oh yeah. 

Henry Harrison: And I enjoyed, I enjoyed getting outdoors and meeting the people and I actually did an internship at Coopers & Lybrand too, by the way, while I was in college. Really, this is crazy.

And, and government contracts. And I decided that that wasn't gonna be my, 'cause I was in from Arlington, Virginia, the Washington DC area. So government contracts is a natural, that was 

Burt Copeland: huge. 

Henry Harrison: Yeah. I decided that that [00:26:00] probably wasn't gonna be my it was hard to see what was getting done. You couldn't go back and look at the project that had been built, like you were saying in construction.

Exactly. So that's why I loved home building and I jumped into that and that was fun. 

Burt Copeland: And I did banking for a little bit coming outta grad school because like, oh, let's go explore the finance side. Intellectually it was great, but you never really felt like you were building something like you do inside of business.

And that to me is very gratifying to seeing the layers of what you are doing over time. 'cause that metaphor of it's your baby is extraordinarily real for most business owners and entrepreneurs. In fact, the biggest thing for them when they're thinking about selling their business is letting go of that.

And so it's important that they have a transition plan. In fact, that's one of the things that we do. We have four, if you will, diagnostic services that we've created, and one of them is turning sweat equity into gold. And that's really an assessment about what is it that you want to do next? What is your [00:27:00] next life look like?

Let's start there. Start with the end in mind, and then we're gonna quantify how much money do you need to to fund that next, whether it's charity, does it matter? And then we back from that into what is your current business currently worth versus what does it have to be worth after taxes to fund that next?

And then we start working on changing the value of the enterprise to connect those dots so that they can exit without feeling lost once they're out of their own business. And then another diagnostic service we have is called Insight 29:11. And that's really about structural EBITDA and cashflow performance.

It's also a strategic assessment of your revenues and, and which ones create more value or are diluting value, and then recraft the total strategy to drive enterprise value as well. 

Henry Harrison: What I, what I understand, and you've laid it out clearly, is. Someone can come to you with a specific need, a specific problem, or they can come to you and you can open up a whole [00:28:00] toolbox of things they may not even thought of that can really help them with value.

Burt Copeland: Absolutely. And you know, we created the toolboxes and the one-off assessments because a lot of mid-market CEOs don't really understand what A CFO could do for 'em. So this represents a really low risk way for them to engage A CFO, understand their company from a CFO's eyes. Then be able to quantify the benefits that says, do I want to invest in that or not?

Without getting into some long-term contract going, well, I guess I'll pay you for 20 or 30 or 40 hours a month and I hope it works out okay. So we do this very intentionally so they know exactly what they're investing in, and then they can make a a very open-eyed, discernment type decision about investing or not.

Henry Harrison: What would be to sort of wrap it up, what would be the normal process? Hey, they've heard you here or somewhere else and they say, you know, I wanna contact the firm Burt, you [00:29:00] someone, and just give a call, send an email and 

Burt Copeland: give a call, an email. We also have a, a, a website. You know, contact us. And that's a really good deal.

'cause we're gonna ask you a few questions there about what do we wanna talk about means we're prepared and we're gonna spend an hour, hour and a half with anybody in the world. And our commitment is, is if we're not the right answer. I know a lot of people like Deanna at Venturity, that could be the right answer and we're going to connect you.

In fact, it was just last week that I made a referral into Eddie Bridgers at Seton Hill 'cause he was the better answer for that client. So we try to eliminate the risk about just having a conversation. 'cause our, another one of our mottoes is if I just serve you well, I will be served. Whether that's, whether we do it or somebody else does it, it doesn't matter.

'cause I probably know my competitors better than you. 

Henry Harrison: Well talk about the core a little bit because that's obviously serving something greater than yourself Is the [00:30:00] matter there? I'm sorry, say it again. At the core has a, a motto, oh. I won't quote it 'cause I wasn't in it, but you could learn some of that.

Something bigger than yourself there as well. 

Burt Copeland: Well, I, I really learned that from being totally humbled by my old business, you know, reversing that picture so it's not the Burt show that I'm here for a purpose and let's make sure that that purpose is serving somebody else. So I'm always delighted to go spend an hour with somebody over lunch or whatever and just let's just talk about what's going on and maybe there's unique insight here that you can run with and that's all you need or other topics to explore more fully. There is no wrong answer.

Henry Harrison: Well, what great way to, to wrap up and unless there's something else I think that's you, you had on your mind. I think that's terrific. 

Burt Copeland: No, I really appreciate the opportunity and again, it's, it's great to see you around the building, even on a, a podcast like this. Great to see your face again. Yeah, 

Henry Harrison: we're upstairs, downstairs here, but that was my system so we didn't, we didn't adjust it.

But hey, [00:31:00] thanks so much for coming on. Our pleasure. I know the audience will love it and I'll see you later today. 

Burt Copeland: Alright man. That take take care. Have a good week. Alright, you too. Bye.

podcasts.guestBio: Burt Copeland's entrepreneurial journey began with a construction company that he grew from $7 million to a $30 million run rate. However, the financial crisis of 2008 led to a significant loss, prompting a pivotal shift in his career. This experience inspired Burt to establish New Life CFO, with a mission to guide other entrepreneurs away from similar pitfalls. At New Life CFO, Burt leverages his hard-earned insights to provide strategic financial leadership, focusing on sustainable growth and value creation for businesses.

podcasts.guestBio: Hugh Massie is the Executive Chairman and Founder of DNA Behavior, a global leader in behavioral data analytics. With over 20 years of experience, Hugh has been at the forefront of integrating psychology with financial decision-making, helping organizations worldwide understand and engage people more effectively. His work in behavioral economics has transformed how businesses approach leadership, client engagement, and personal development.
keyInsights: In this episode, Hugh Massie shares his journey from a wealth management professional to a leader in behavioral data analytics. He discusses the founding of DNA Behavior and its mission to decode human behavior using AI technology.
podcasts.subheadline: Exploring the Intersection of Psychology and Finance

news.title: Henry Harrison Facilitates $20MM Debt Financing Preliminary Approval for ASIC Network, Inc
news.content:

This collaboration bears testament to the convergence of visionary insights and financial expertise, aiming to catalyze transformative change within the technology and financial sectors.

ASIC Network, Inc, with its forward-looking approach and pioneering spirit, has consistently pushed the boundaries of blockchain technology. This strategic debt financing initiative, masterminded by Henry Harrison, serves as a cornerstone for the realization of ASIC Network, Inc's ambitious expansion and innovation strategies.

Henry Harrison: Architect of Financial Success

Henry Harrison, distinguished by his extensive portfolio of financial achievements, has once again showcased his ability to navigate complex financial landscapes. His involvement in the preliminary approval of $20 million debt financing further underscores his reputation as an architect of financial success for his clients.

Navigating Uncharted Terrain

The partnership between Henry Harrison and ASIC Network, Inc epitomizes a strategic alliance geared towards navigating uncharted financial terrain. This milestone achievement signifies the culmination of meticulous planning, visionary thinking, and a shared commitment to unlocking new avenues of growth and prosperity.

Leveraging Expertise, Forging Synergy

The collaboration between Henry Harrison and ASIC Network, Inc underscores the symbiotic relationship between financial prowess and technological innovation. As both entities leverage their expertise, they forge a synergy that not only secures the preliminary approval of significant debt financing but also paves the way for a future marked by groundbreaking advancements.

Henry Harrison's reputation as a preeminent finance expert precedes him. With a track record of consistently delivering remarkable financial solutions, Harrison has become a trusted partner for businesses and individuals seeking financial excellence. For more information, visit debtfi.io.

About ASIC Network, Inc

Recognized for its unwavering commitment to pushing the boundaries of what's possible, the company continues to drive transformative change across industries. For more information, please visit asicnetwork.io.

As Henry Harrison and ASIC Network, Inc chart a course for progress through this monumental debt financing achievement, their combined expertise and shared vision promise to redefine industry standards. The preliminary approval of $20 million debt financing is not only a testament to their capabilities but also a harbinger of the remarkable transformations that lie ahead. news.title: Henry Harrison Invested Into the Future of Green Energy
news.content:
[rank_math_breadcrumb]

News Distribution: The Henry Harrison Family Has Invested again into the future of Green Energy. The Investment was into a Waste to Waste-to-Energy Company that has Gained a Coveted Spot at COP 28

Dallas, TX, August 11, 2023 — Henry Harrison’s family Investments are making a name for themselves in forward-looking ventures. Henry has made a decisive move that resonates with the environmental ethos of our times. With resolute intention, he has secured a substantial equity stake in a pioneering Private Green Energy company. This dynamic partnership brings forth groundbreaking proprietary technology, poised to greatly improve Waste to Energy services and equipment. This strategic maneuver has not only reaffirmed Henry Harrison’s commitment to sustainable innovation but has also earned the accolade of a coveted presence on the grand stage of COP 28, scheduled for 2023 in the vibrant city of Dubai.

Elevating Green Energy Landscape

In a bold stride toward a greener future, Harrison Family Investments has solidified its partnership with a cutting-edge Private Green Energy enterprise. This strategic union merges Harrison's impeccable financial acumen with the Green Energy company's proprietary technology. The result is a game-changing approach to Waste to Energy conversion, promising more efficient and environmentally conscious solutions. This visionary collaboration embarks on a mission to redefine sustainability norms and introduce innovative paradigms within the renewable energy sector.

Leading the Charge at COP 28

The recognition of Harrison Family Investments' resolute commitment arrives in the form of an invitation to COP 28's prestigious Green Zone in Dubai. This esteemed global platform is renowned for assembling the most influential minds and revolutionary technologies in the realm of environmental conservation. This Waste to Energy Company’s inclusion underscores the pivotal role it is expected to play in shaping a sustainable future. Positioned at the epicenter of discourse and innovation, the company’s management will engage with world leaders, industry experts, and passionate eco-advocates, showcasing their technology poised to redefine Waste to Energy conversion.

A Visionary Partnership

At the heart of this transformative collaboration lies the Private Green Energy company's proprietary technology. Fueled by groundbreaking innovation, this technology promises a dramatic leap in the efficiency of Waste to Energy services and equipment. This synergy of financial prowess and technological ingenuity positions the company as a driving force in ushering the world into a new era of responsible energy management.

A Glimpse of the Future

The partnership's success not only cements Harrison Family Investments' legacy as visionary stewards of sustainable progress but also paves the way for a future where Waste to Energy solutions are robust, efficient, and environmentally conscious. As the world turns its gaze toward Dubai for COP 28, the presence of this company in the Green Zone is a testament to the conglomerate's unwavering dedication to fostering innovation, collaboration, and a greener planet.

news.title: Surviving the Scorch: The Economic and Environmental Impact of Texas Heat Waves
news.content:
[rank_math_breadcrumb] Economic and Environmental Impact of Texas Heat Waves: In the vast expanse of Texas, where everything is known to be bigger, there's one thing that often goes beyond expectations—the blistering heat. Texas heat waves are not just a matter of discomfort; they have far-reaching consequences that extend to the economy, environment, and daily lives of its residents. In this article, we dive deep into the scorching reality of the Lone Star State's heat waves, exploring the costs, challenges, and potential solutions.

The Nature of Texas Heat Waves

When summer arrives in Texas, temperatures soar to astonishing heights that can even make the sun feel envious. The state experiences prolonged periods of intense heat, often accompanied by drought conditions. This meteorological phenomenon is what Texans refer to as a heat wave—a period of excessively hot weather lasting several days or weeks.

The Economic Toll

The scorching temperatures of Texas heat waves aren't just a topic for small talk; they carry a hefty price tag. The strain on energy resources during these periods leads to escalated electricity demand, resulting in skyrocketing utility bills for consumers and businesses alike. The energy grid groans under the pressure, occasionally leading to rolling blackouts that disrupt daily operations and cost businesses millions in lost productivity.

Environmental Challenges

The ecological impact of Texas heat waves is a cause for concern. With higher temperatures and decreased rainfall, water bodies evaporate faster, leading to reduced water availability for both consumption and agriculture. Additionally, heat waves exacerbate air quality issues, as higher temperatures facilitate the formation of ground-level ozone, a harmful air pollutant.

Counting the Costs: Economic and Environmental Impact of Texas Heat Waves

Economic Losses

The economic repercussions of Texas heat waves are substantial. From increased energy consumption to reduced worker productivity, the overall cost runs into billions of dollars. The agricultural sector takes a hit as crops wither under the unrelenting sun, leading to food shortages and escalating prices.

Health Consequences

The health of Texans is put on the line during heat waves. Vulnerable populations, such as the elderly and children, face a higher risk of heat-related illnesses, including heat exhaustion and heatstroke. Overburdened healthcare facilities struggle to keep up with the influx of patients seeking relief from heat-related ailments.

Searching for Solutions

Sustainable Energy Practices

To mitigate the impact of heat waves, Texas is shifting towards sustainable energy practices. Investing in solar and wind energy not only reduces the strain on traditional power sources but also helps curb greenhouse gas emissions. This transition is not only environmentally responsible but also economically beneficial in the long run.

Urban Planning and Green Spaces

Cities in Texas are reimagining urban planning by incorporating green spaces and reflective materials in infrastructure. The creation of parks and green roofs not only provides respite for residents but also helps lower the overall temperature of urban areas, combating the "urban heat island" effect.

news.title: Why is Texas Ranked #1 in America for "Best Business Climate"
news.content:
[rank_math_breadcrumb] Why is Texas Ranked #1 in America for "Best Business Climate"? If you're an entrepreneur looking to establish or expand your business in the United States, you might have heard that Texas holds the prestigious title of being ranked #1 for the "Best Business Climate." But what exactly sets Texas apart and makes it an ideal destination for businesses? In this article, we'll delve into the key factors that contribute to Texas's top-ranking business climate, exploring its business-friendly policies, economic diversity, and remarkable growth opportunities.

Tax-Friendly Environment

Texas proudly boasts its tax-friendly environment, which plays a pivotal role in attracting businesses. The state has no personal income tax or corporate tax, making it an appealing destination for business owners and entrepreneurs. This tax advantage allows companies to retain more of their profits, thus facilitating growth and reinvestment.

Regulatory Policies: Navigating with Ease

Texas simplifies the bureaucratic processes that often hinder business growth in other states. The regulatory framework is designed to be efficient and responsive, enabling businesses to navigate licenses, permits, and approvals with relative ease. This streamlined approach saves time and resources for businesses, fostering a supportive climate for their development.

Thriving Economic Diversity

The Lone Star State's economy is a tapestry of diverse industries, from energy and technology to healthcare and agriculture. This diversity provides businesses with multiple avenues for collaboration and growth, reducing their vulnerability to economic downturns in any single sector.

The Power of the Energy Industry

Texas holds a prominent position in the energy sector. With abundant oil and natural gas reserves and a robust renewable energy market, the state attracts energy companies seeking a conducive environment for innovation and expansion.

Workforce Talents: From Skilled to Tech-Savvy

The Texan workforce is a blend of traditional skills and modern expertise. From skilled labor for industries like manufacturing to a growing pool of tech-savvy professionals, businesses have access to a versatile talent pool to meet their diverse needs.

Infrastructure and Accessibility

The state's strategic geographical location and well-developed infrastructure make it a logistical hub for domestic and international trade. Access to ports, railroads, highways, and airports simplifies the transportation of goods, making Texas an ideal base for businesses with distribution and export needs.

A Pro-Entrepreneurial Mindset

Texans are known for their independent spirit and pro-business attitude. This culture not only fosters an entrepreneurial spirit but also encourages networking and collaboration, creating an ecosystem where businesses can thrive together.

Innovation and Research Hubs

Texas is home to renowned research institutions and innovation hubs. Universities like the University of Texas and Texas A&M University contribute to cutting-edge research, fostering innovation and providing businesses with opportunities for collaboration.

Quality of Life: More than Just Business

Beyond business, Texas offers a high quality of life. Affordable housing, diverse cultural experiences, and recreational opportunities make it an attractive destination for employees and their families, enhancing employee satisfaction and retention.

Rapid Growth and Expansion

The state's population growth and economic expansion are remarkable. This growth translates into a steady influx of potential customers and clients, providing businesses with a broad consumer base and opportunities for expansion.

FAQ

  1. Is Texas really corporate tax-free for businesses? Yes, Texas does not impose state income tax or corporate tax on businesses, which is a significant advantage for entrepreneurs.
  2. How does Texas attract technology companies? Texas's favorable tax policies, skilled workforce, and presence of tech hubs like Austin make it appealing for technology companies.
  3. Are there any incentives for startups in Texas? Texas provides various incentives like grants, funding, and accelerators to encourage startup growth.
  4. What industries have seen significant growth in Texas? Industries such as technology, healthcare, energy, and manufacturing have experienced substantial growth in Texas.
  5. How does Texas support a high quality of life? Texas offers affordable living, diverse cultural amenities, and recreational options that contribute to an excellent quality of life for residents.

news.title: Governor Abbott's Role in Texas' Economic Triumph: TAB Summit Highlights
news.content:
[rank_math_breadcrumb]

TAB Summit Highlights

In a monumental stride towards solidifying Texas' economic prowess, Governor Greg Abbott was bestowed with the 2023 Economic Trailblazer Award by the Texas Association of Business (TAB). This recognition underscores his tireless endeavors in propelling Texas as the unequivocal economic powerhouse of America. The occasion was marked by a virtual fireside conversation at the TAB South Texas Development Summit, where Governor Abbott delved into his legislative triumphs for the year. His strategic vision not only bolsters the Lone Star State's workforce but also nurtures an environment ripe for economic expansion.

Celebrating Legislative Victories

In an illuminating dialogue with TAB's CEO, Glenn Hamer, Governor Abbott lauded Texas' accomplishments on the legislative front, poised to invigorate the state's economic landscape. Foremost among these victories is the monumental property tax cut, an unprecedented move etching its place in the annals of Texan history. A robust reduction in local red tape and regulations complements this landmark initiative, aiming to stimulate economic growth across every corner of Texas.

A Grateful Acknowledgment

Governor Abbott extended his gratitude towards TAB for its collective leadership, acknowledging their pivotal role in steering Texas' businesses towards prosperity. His words resonated with a room filled with business luminaries, operators, and stakeholders driving Texas' economic evolution. The synergy of these efforts has culminated in an unparalleled budget surplus, paving the way for unprecedented opportunities. This financial windfall was unwaveringly returned to the taxpayers, a testimony to the administration's commitment to the state's welfare.

Unveiling the Power of Unity

A collaborative spirit permeated the legislative process, as the House and Senate exhibited remarkable cohesion. Their concerted endeavors bore fruit in the form of a remarkable $18 billion in property tax cuts. This monumental decision reverberates not only within the households of Texas but reverberates through the entrepreneurial landscape as well.

Propelling Economic Advancement

Before an audience comprising 130 prominent TAB members, the Port of Corpus Christi, members of the United Corpus Christi Chamber of Commerce, and esteemed local officials, Governor Abbott underscored additional legislative milestones from the 88th Legislative Session. The unveiling of the Texas CHIPS Act and the inception of the Texas Space Commission stand as a testament to Texas' unwavering commitment to economic expansion.

A Symbolic Pinnacle

The summit bore witness to a symbolic act as Governor Abbott ceremoniously inked his endorsement onto House Bill 5. This legislative gem augments Texas' economic arsenal by equipping it with essential economic development tools. These tools, designed to attract an influx of economic ventures, are poised to herald an era of unprecedented progress.

The Power of Economic Incentives

House Bill 5, sponsored by Schwertner, introduces a pivotal economic incentive mechanism, cementing Texas as an irresistible hub for substantial capital investments and thriving manufacturing endeavors. This initiative resonates with robust reporting and transparency obligations, embodying a commitment to a thriving business environment while fostering accountability. In summation, Governor Abbott's unwavering dedication has positioned Texas at the zenith of economic prosperity. His strategic prowess, coupled with monumental legislative successes, underscores Texas' role as an economic trailblazer. As the state surges forward, driven by unity, innovation, and foresight, the nation watches with bated breath to witness Texas' unrivaled economic tapestry unfurl.
news.excerpt: Governor Greg Abbott was bestowed with the 2023 Economic Trailblazer Award by the Texas Association of Business (TAB). This recognition underscores his tireless endeavors in propelling Texas as the unequivocal economic powerhouse of America.

news.title: Unlocking the Power Beneath: Texas Legislation Defines Ownership of Geothermal Energy
news.content:
[rank_math_breadcrumb] Texas Legislation Defines Ownership of Geothermal Energy: In a groundbreaking move, the Lone Star State, Texas, has recently enacted Senate Bill 785, reshaping the energy landscape by officially recognizing the ownership of geothermal energy resources and their associated byproducts. This transformative legislation, effective as of June 18, 2023, has immense implications for landowners, the energy sector, and the environment.

Senate Bill 785

Empowering Landowners

The heart of this legislation lies in its allocation of ownership rights. As per Senate Bill 785, the geothermal energy beneath the land's surface now belongs to either the landowner or the owner of the surface estate. This bold move gives individuals and entities a direct stake in the vast potential of geothermal energy, a previously underutilized resource.

Unanimous Support

Senate Bill 785 received overwhelming support, securing two-thirds of the votes in each legislative chamber. What sets this bill apart is that it didn't require the Governor's signature or a veto; it automatically became law. This underscores its importance and broad appeal.

Navigating the Legal Terrain

Redefining Geothermal Resources

The bill introduces crucial amendments to Section 141.003(5) of the Natural Resources Code, providing a clear definition of heat as a by-product of geothermal energy and its associated resources. Importantly, it distinguishes these resources from mineral, oil, or gas assets, reinforcing their unique status.

Establishing Ownership

Section 141.004 of the Natural Resources Code is a game-changer, as it lays down the foundation for ownership rights. This section unequivocally states that geothermal energy and its associated resources beneath the land's surface are considered real property. These rights are granted to either the landowner or, in cases where surface and mineral estates have been separated, the surface estate owner.

Drilling for Prosperity

The ownership rights outlined in this legislation empower individuals and their lessees, heirs, or assignees to explore and extract geothermal energy and its associated resources. This move opens up exciting opportunities for renewable energy production and economic growth, positioning Texas at the forefront of the geothermal energy revolution.

Limitations and Clarifications

To maintain clarity, the legislation includes a provision. It clarifies that the ownership rights do not extend to minerals dissolved or otherwise contained in groundwater, including hot brines. This distinction is essential to prevent confusion and disputes over resource boundaries.

Sec. 141.004 OWNERSHIP OF GEOTHERMAL ENERGY AND ASSOCIATED RESOURCES

(a) Except as otherwise expressly provided by a conveyance, contract, deed, reservation, exception, limitation, lease, or other binding obligation, the geothermal energy and associated resources below the surface of land are owned as real property by (1) the landowner; or (2) if the surface estate and the mineral estate of the land have been severed, the owner of the surface estate of the land. (b) Subject to the provisions of this chapter, the property rights described by this section entitle the owner of the geothermal energy and associated resources below the surface of land and the owner’s lessee, heir, or assignee to drill for and produce the geothermal energy and associated resources. (c) This section does not apply to minerals dissolved or otherwise contained in groundwater, including in hot brines.

news.title: Alamo Drafthouse Locations in North Texas Close Abruptly
news.content:
The company operating Alamo Drafthouse movie theaters in North Texas has declared bankruptcy, leading to the sudden closure of all six of its locations. This unexpected shutdown impacts 600 employees across five locations in North Texas—Dallas, Richardson, Las Colinas, Lake Highlands, and Denton—as well as a theater in Woodbury, Minnesota, near St. Paul.

Reasons Behind the Bankruptcy

In a press release issued Thursday morning, the franchisee, Two is One, One is None, LLC, cited several financial challenges as the cause of the bankruptcy. High franchise fees and the obligation to keep its least profitable locations running were major factors contributing to their financial woes. Despite efforts to reach all affected employees before the public announcement, the closure still came as a shock. The franchisee has committed to offering references for these employees.

Impact on the Local Community and Employees

The closures have a significant impact on the local communities and the 600 employees who now face sudden unemployment. The Alamo Drafthouse locations in Austin and other parts of the country remain unaffected by this bankruptcy. Gift card holders, season pass holders, and Victory members are advised to contact Alamo Drafthouse corporate for assistance.

Statement from Alamo Drafthouse Corporate

A spokesperson for Alamo Drafthouse corporate expressed deep disappointment over the franchisee's bankruptcy and immediate closure. The corporate team is working diligently to restore operations in the affected cities. Meanwhile, all other Alamo Drafthouse locations continue to operate as usual, with ongoing plans for expansion nationwide.

The Broader Context: Challenges in the Movie Theater Industry

The bankruptcy and closures come at a challenging time for the movie theater industry, which has struggled to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. Box office sales over Memorial Day Weekend were 42% below 2019 levels, highlighting the ongoing difficulties faced by the industry. The pandemic's impact on consumer behavior and the rise of streaming services have further compounded these challenges.

Future Prospects for Alamo Drafthouse

Despite the current setback, Alamo Drafthouse corporate remains optimistic about the future. They are committed to reopening the closed locations and continuing their expansion efforts across the country. This incident underscores the importance of strategic financial management and adaptability in the ever-evolving entertainment industry. The sudden closure of all Dallas-area Alamo Drafthouse locations due to bankruptcy marks a significant moment for the North Texas film community. While this development brings immediate challenges, there is hope that Alamo Drafthouse will bounce back and continue to provide unique cinematic experiences to moviegoers in the future. For now, affected employees and patrons are encouraged to seek assistance from Alamo Drafthouse corporate as they navigate this transition.

news.title: Celina, Texas: America’s Fastest-Growing City
news.content:
Celina, a small city located about 40 miles north of downtown Dallas, is making headlines as one of America’s fastest-growing cities. This once-overlooked town is now attracting new residents with its freshly built homes and close-knit community.

A Charming Small-Town Atmosphere

In Celina, the American flags that grace the sidewalks and the country tunes that fill local businesses create a nostalgic small-town charm. Shop owners greet customers by name, and neighbors exchange warm hellos while driving their children to and from school in shiny golf carts.

Rapid Population Growth

The hallmarks of urban life, such as bustling shopping malls and large parking lots, are noticeably absent in Celina. The city only welcomed its first Starbucks in 2022. However, what Celina does have in abundance is newly built homes. According to the latest US Census Bureau figures, the city experienced a remarkable 26.6% population surge from July 2022 to July 2023, far exceeding the nation's 0.5% growth rate.

Development and Migration Trends

In 2010, Celina had only 6,028 residents. By 2020, this number had increased to 16,739, and by 2023, the population had skyrocketed to 43,317. Analysis of census migration data reveals that most new residents in Collin County, including Celina, come from Texas ZIP codes, as well as California, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, and Missouri. There is also a significant number of people relocating from Africa, Asia, Central America, and Europe.

The Appeal of Celina

Texas has become a hotspot for domestic migration within the United States. While major cities like Austin, Dallas, and Houston have long driven the state's population growth, smaller areas like Celina are now leading the charge. Their rising popularity is partly due to their down-to-earth lifestyle, relatively low costs, and availability of new homes. "We're growing at about 20% every year," says Ryan Tubbs, the mayor of Celina since May 2023. "It's just astronomical growth when you think about the influx of residents and the number of housing permits. Even so, our vision is to maintain that small-town feel, no matter how big we get."

Economic Development and Accessibility

Celina's transformation from corn and cotton farmland into a rapidly expanding city is part of a developmental wave sweeping across Collin County, which includes nearby cities such as Frisco, Plano, and Prosper. This growth has been greatly influenced by the ongoing expansion of the North Texas Tollway, which has increased accessibility to previously remote cities. With Celina becoming more accessible, numerous new housing developments led by builders like Taylor Morrison, Toll Brothers, and Highland Homes have heightened the area's appeal. According to the city, from 2010 until June 2024, 15,062 single-family permits have been issued for Celina, many in brand-new master-planned communities.

A Thriving Real Estate Market

The president of Highland Homes, Aaron Graham, highlights Celina's real estate boom. The company specializes in luxury homes within master-planned communities and has built several neighborhoods in Celina since 2020. Home prices in these developments start in the low $500,000s and reach into the millions. By the end of the year, Highland Homes expects to have closed around 2,100 home sales in Celina. The abundance of relatively affordable homes has attracted numerous buyers from the more expensive West and East Coasts. Celina welcomes an average of 830 newcomers monthly, often arriving with higher incomes and larger budgets for home buying.

Community and Economic Growth

With more people living in Celina, the local economy is also growing. Tracy Miller, owner of downtown Celina's home-decor shop, Terramania, reports that sales have steadily increased since opening. The city is constructing a new city hall and expanding its staff to accommodate its growing number of residents.

Maintaining Community Values

Despite rapid growth, Celina remains committed to maintaining its community spirit. This was evident following rainstorms that led to a federal disaster declaration in June for several Texas counties, including Collin County. Residents banded together to form volunteer groups, offering prayers and support to those affected. "In Celina, everyone is there for each other," says Julissa Casas, a real estate agent who also volunteered for the storm relief efforts. "We get a lot of volunteers, and the city does a great job of organizing. That's what I love about the city—it is growing, but it still has a small-town community feel."

Summary

Celina, Texas, is a shining example of a small city experiencing astronomical growth while retaining its charming small-town atmosphere. With its rapid population increase, new housing developments, and strong community spirit, Celina is poised to continue its remarkable transformation. Henry Harrison Dallas Texas Podcast Season 3

news.title: Dallas-Fort Worth Dominates Commercial Real Estate in 2024
news.content:
Dallas-Fort Worth continues to reign supreme in the commercial real estate market, holding its top position in real estate investments for 2024. According to the latest U.S. Investor Intentions Survey by CBRE Research, this thriving metropolitan area has topped investors’ lists for three consecutive years. Following closely are Miami, Raleigh, North Carolina, and Nashville, Tennessee, as the most preferred investment markets.

The Challenges and Optimism in Real Estate Investment

Despite several challenges, investor sentiment has significantly improved. The survey highlights that interest rates, tight credit conditions, and differing buyer and seller expectations are the main obstacles to commercial real estate investment this year. However, the optimism is palpable, with over 60% of respondents planning to purchase more real estate in 2024 than in 2023, a stark contrast to the mere 16% in 2023 compared to 2022.

Multifamily, Industrial, and Retail Properties in Demand

Investors are showing a strong preference for multifamily real estate, particularly Class A properties. Industrial and logistics properties are also high on their list. Retail investors are most interested in grocery-anchored centers, aligning perfectly with the upcoming H-E-B openings in the area. Meanwhile, nearly 60% of office investors are leaning towards prime/trophy office properties, which aligns with the new developments in the Cultural District and along West Seventh Street.

Pickleball Takes Over West Fort Worth

In a fun twist, West Fort Worth is about to get a new hotspot for pickleball enthusiasts. The Picklr is set to open on May 24 at 1705 S. Cherry Lane, taking over a former Dirt Cheap location. This 34,000-square-foot facility boasts 11 indoor courts with high-quality, outdoor-style surfacing, a full pro shop, private event space, unlimited league play, tournaments, and open play.

Expansion Plans for The Picklr

The franchise owner of The Picklr’s West Fort Worth and Hurst locations, Zion Meer, is thrilled about the new addition. “Bringing The Picklr to West Fort Worth, Texas, means our community will benefit from the best-in-class in indoor pickleball,” he said. The North Texas locations are part of a larger national expansion, with 262 new locations planned across 36 states, featuring more than 2,000 courts over the next few years.

Major Real Estate Deals in Fort Worth

The commercial real estate scene in Fort Worth is bustling with new deals. Kurita America has leased a massive 90,278 square feet at South Fort Worth Commerce Center. Andrew Johnson with Colliers represented the tenant, while Matt Carthey and Thomas Grafton with Holt Lunsford Commercial represented the landlord, IDI Logistics. Another significant deal includes Air Relief Technologies Inc., which has leased 52,788 square feet at 5909 Eden Drive, Haltom City. Michael Newsome with NAI Robert Lynn represented the tenant, with Thomas Grafton and Trey Goodspeed from Holt Lunsford Commercial representing the landlord. Additionally, Courtside Couture has leased 316 square feet at Ridglea Village, Fort Worth, with Ross Moncrief from Holt Lunsford Commercial representing the landlord, Sherman Way Investors LP.

Summary

The Dallas-Fort Worth area continues to dominate the commercial real estate market in 2024, maintaining its position as the top choice for investors for the third consecutive year, according to CBRE Research's U.S. Investor Intentions Survey. Despite challenges such as high interest rates and tight credit conditions, investor sentiment has improved, with over 60% planning to purchase more real estate this year. The most sought-after investments include multifamily properties, industrial and logistics spaces, and grocery-anchored retail centers. Meanwhile, West Fort Worth is set to become a hotspot for pickleball with the opening of The Picklr, a large indoor facility. The local real estate market also sees significant deals, such as Kurita America's lease at South Fort Worth Commerce Center and Air Relief Technologies' lease in Haltom City.

news.title: Dallas Black Chamber of Commerce Distributes $30,000 in Grants to Minority Enterprises
news.content: The Dallas Black Chamber of Commerce (DBCC) is poised to inject financial life into burgeoning businesses. In concert with Office Depot, the chamber has unveiled 'Elevate Together,' a groundbreaking initiative to empower minority-owned enterprises. Five years ago, Amber Jackson birthed Glitz Optical. "Glitz Optical is a luxury mobile concept," she explained. "We cater to clients who don't have much time in their day. So we come to their home or office or meet them at their local coffee shop." A seasoned optician with 17 years of experience, Jackson was the beneficiary of a $5,000 grant last year, enabling her to broaden her operational scope to include in-house eyewear manufacturing. "With those funds, we were able to cut out the middleman of having the lab because I also know how to cut the lenses," she said. This financial boom originated from the DBCC in collaboration with Office Depot. "This partnership really came from the Greater Dallas Hispanic Chamber. They were already working with the Office Depot corporation," said Harrison Blair, president and CEO of the Dallas Black Chamber of Commerce. "They said, ‘Hey, Harrison. The Dallas Black Chamber of Commerce would be a great partner for a program like this. Would you consider working with ODP?’ And they said they'll give you money that you can give away. You don’t have to twist my arm for a good time." The grant program was inaugurated last year and saw its first cycle of funding. This year, Office Depot again gave the chamber $30,000 to support small businesses. "You never know. Yours might be the diamond in the rough, the needle in the haystack," said Blair. For Lorin Carter’s C-Suite Equity Consulting, the grant was a game-changer. "We were one of the perfect candidates to receive the grant," she said. "The grant is all about addressing systemic barriers and racial disparities in business, and that’s exactly what we work to do in all of the things and the services that we offer." "We've seen a lot of impact from it, so we're very excited about what it's doing," said Blair. Source: Yahoo Finance
